IUCN.common.name: Allen's Swamp Monkey
notes: McGraw (1994) states that this species was seen mostly on the ground, supporting previous findings that they are semi-terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Hairy-eared Dwarf Lemur
notes: ADW: Allocebus trichotis: INFORMATION (animaldiversity.org)  "rarest of the extant lemurs, little is known about it's behavior" Nocturnal. Exhibits torpor, which can occur in leaf litter at base of a tree.

IUCN.common.name: L'Hoest's Monkey
notes: Kaplin and Moermond (2000) report this species uses the ground 38% of the time. This would qualify as not terrestrial in the binary categorization, along with the 3 Allochrocebus spp. below, if >40% ground use is the definition

IUCN.common.name: Preuss’s Monkey
notes: Gartlan and Struhsaker (1972) or Gautier-Hion (1988) report this species uses the ground 35% of the time

IUCN.common.name: Bioko Preuss’s Monkey
notes: spp. refers to island population. Kirchner (2004) estimates 25.5% of observations on ground.

IUCN.common.name: Sun-tailed Monkey
notes: estimates 33.7% terrestriality. Percent fruit data from semi-free ranging group study referenced here: https://neprimateconservancy.org/sun-tailed-monkey/

IUCN.common.name: Ursine Howler Monkey
notes: Weight data from IUCN, averaged for males and females, weight listed as same as A.seniculus.

IUCN.common.name: Red-handed Howler Monkey
notes: "Habitat use by Chiropotes satanas utahicki and Syntopic platarrhines in Eastern Amazonia"

IUCN.common.name: Spix's Red-handed Howler Monkey
notes: Weight data from IUCN, averaged for males and females

IUCN.common.name: Juruá Red Howler Monkey
notes: IUCN lists the size as similar to A.seniculus. Male at 7.62kg and females at 6.02. Average being 6.82

IUCN.common.name: Black Howler Monkey
notes: Juca et al. (2020) refers to Alouatta species, including this one, as all arboreal

IUCN.common.name: Ecuadorian Mantled Howler Monkey
notes: Cervera et al. (2015), Tleimat (2021) MA thesis. Neither reference contains detailed habitat use data, or mention of strata use

IUCN.common.name: Yucatán Black Howler Monkey
notes: Serio-Silva et al. (2019) quantified terrestrial behavior of A.pigra in highly fragmented forests. Refers to species as primarily arboreal

IUCN.common.name: Bolivian Red Howler Monkey
notes: Body mass and diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Brumback's Night Monkey
notes: arboreal status and fruit percentage cited by https://www.gbif.org/species/190702082

IUCN.common.name: Grey-handed Night Monkey
notes: Munoz-Delgado et al. (2021) describes species as strictly arboreal but the paper is not about habitat use or strata, so contains no data. diet: Montilla et al. (2021) https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10764-020-00192-1. Weight data from Montilla et al. 2021

IUCN.common.name: Colombian Night Monkey
notes: Weight data from Montilla et al. 2021 https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10764-020-00192-1

IUCN.common.name: Lorenz Von Liburnau’s Woolly Lemur
notes: "Habitat use and support preference of two free-ranging saltatory lemurs" - study doesn't mention any ground use at all

IUCN.common.name: Ramantsoavana's Southern Woolly Lemur
notes: IUCN page says this species has not been systematically studied in the wild, but states this species is arboreal

IUCN.common.name: Sambirano Woolly Lemur
notes: IUCN page says species has not been studied in the wild

IUCN.common.name: White Bald-headed Uakari
notes: reports data from Ayres (1986) dissertation. Couldn't find the text.

IUCN.common.name: Red Uacari
notes: reports unpublished data from Bennett, Bodmer, and Puentes who have never seen this species on the ground in years of study

IUCN.common.name: Black-headed Uacari
notes: IUCN page says this species has never been seen descending to the ground

IUCN.common.name: Black-headed Uacari
notes: reports data from multiple published and unpublished sources

IUCN.common.name: Blond Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Coimbra-Filho’s Titi Monkey
notes: reports on a 33 month study period that this species spent 0.6% of time on the ground, mostly to forage on young leaves

IUCN.common.name: Black-handed Titi
notes: "The distributions, habitat use, and conservation status of three Atlantic Forest Monkeys in an agroforestry/forest mosaic in Southern Bahia, Brazil"

IUCN.common.name: Black-fronted Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Atlantic Titi
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Goeldi’s Monkey
notes: "Habitat use and ranging behavior of C.goeldi" reference finds seasonality in ground use (0-3% monthly), with overall annual ground use estimated at 1%. Study was conducted in areas of mixed forest, primary to secondary recovering forest from selective logging

IUCN.common.name: Ecuadorian White-fronted Capuchin
notes: Campos and Jack (2013) refer to this species as an arboreal primate. No data on ground use though.

IUCN.common.name: Shock-headed Capuchin
notes: Can't find primary references, but IUCN page says they are arboreal but occasionally forage on the ground

IUCN.common.name: Panamanian White-throated Capuchin
notes: Found increased terrestriality of this species on island sites that lack mammalian terrestrial predators

IUCN.common.name: Guinan Weeper Capuchin
notes: "Positional behavior and substrate use in wild adult bearded capuchin monkeys", table 3, original references included. Referencing population in Venezuelan rainforest

IUCN.common.name: Agile Mangabey
notes: Shah (2003) Refers to species as semi-terrestrial. Ch.1 detailed data on ground use by sex and season. Males are more terrestrial than females, both peaking in dry season. Ground use percentage ranges from 12% - 22%. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014), cited by https://worldspecies.org/ntaxa/915108#cite_2

IUCN.common.name: Sooty Mangabey
notes: McGraw (1998) has detailed data on strata use, showing over 75% of locomotion, travel, and foraging takes place on the ground.  Range and Noe 2002 estimate 80% ground use.

IUCN.common.name: White-naped Mangabey
notes: "largely terrestrial mode of life in the wild"

IUCN.common.name: Red-capped Mangabey
notes: Mitani (1989) shows that this species is mostly terrestrial during social, resting, and moving behaviors, but is more arboreal for feeding.

IUCN.common.name: Diana Monkey
notes: McGraw (1998) detailed data on strata use, showing this species uses the ground 2.2% of the time for locomotion, travel, and foraging.

IUCN.common.name: Dryas Monkey
notes: camera trap study did not capture any ground use, but earlier reports (Kuroda et al. 1985) state this species frequently forages on the ground. Detection by camera traps is likely constrained by the preference for thickets.

IUCN.common.name: Lesula
notes: terrestriality inferred from CT capture rates compared to highly arboreal sympatric primates

IUCN.common.name: Zanzibar Sykes’s Monkey
notes: 2.5% ground use. Diet data from Foerster (2009) Dissertation

IUCN.common.name: Montagne d'Ambre Dwarf Lemur
notes: described as arboreal but no other information is available about its ecology and behavior

IUCN.common.name: Crossley's Dwarf Lemur
notes: hibernates underground for months at a time. No other habitat use data can be found

IUCN.common.name: Geoffroy's Dwarf Lemur
notes: no observations of this species using terrestrial camera traps, only arboreal camera traps. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014) as cited by https://worldspecies.org/ntaxa/914969#cite_2

IUCN.common.name: Fat-tailed Dwarf Lemur
notes: "Habitat utilization of three sympatric Cheirogaleid lemurs", hibernates underground or in tree holes for months at a time. No other habitat use data found

IUCN.common.name: Sibree's Dwarf Lemur
notes: active period occupies tree holes and hibernates underground

IUCN.common.name: Thomas' Dwarf Lemur
notes: showed vertical stratification with sympatric lemurs, used lowest strata.

IUCN.common.name: Yellow-handed Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Collared Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Colombian Black-handed Titi
notes: IUCN states there is no ecological data on this species. Only first described in 2016 in ATWP

IUCN.common.name: Widow Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Widow Monkey
notes: IUCN states there is no ecological data on this species. Only first described in 2016 in ATWP

IUCN.common.name: Collared Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Bearded Saki
notes: reports on multiple published data showing zero to very few terrestrial observations

IUCN.common.name: Reddish-brown bearded saki
notes: refers to the highly arboreal nature of this species

IUCN.common.name: Black Bearded Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events

IUCN.common.name: Uta Hick’s Bearded Saki
notes: "Habitat use by Chiropotes satanas utahicki and Syntopic platarrhines in Eastern Amazonia"

IUCN.common.name: Grivet Monkey
notes: "Ecological relations and niche separation between sympatric terrestrial primates in Ethiopia", percentage is based on number of individuals in the trees or on the ground for all scans. Diet data from IUCN page.

IUCN.common.name: Malbrouck Monkey
notes: 35% ground use inferred from Ch. Pygerythrus

IUCN.common.name: Bale Monkey
notes: reports comparison of ground use between continuous forest dwellers (2.3%) and fragmented forest (36.5%)

IUCN.common.name: Vervet Monkey
notes: Body mass data from Primate Info Net

IUCN.common.name: Tantalus Monkey
notes: 35% ground use inferred from Ch. pygerythrus

IUCN.common.name: Peter's Angolan Colobus
notes: describes ground use for 3 troops, each under 1%. Here, I use the average of the groups.

IUCN.common.name: Adolf Friedrichs’s Angolan Colobus
notes: estimates 0.08% of observations were on the ground

IUCN.common.name: King Colobus
notes: McGraw (1998) data on strata use finds this species to use the ground 0.4% of the time

IUCN.common.name: Southern Patas Monkey
notes: refers to this species as largely terrestrial, other sources say semi-terrestrial, but not sure of a percentage

IUCN.common.name: Heuglin’s Patas Monkey
notes: IUCN data deficient. Can't find habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: White-collared Lemur
notes: Diet data from Ralainasolo et al. (2008) https://www.ajol.info/index.php/mcd/article/view/44134

IUCN.common.name: Red-bellied Lemur
notes: no observations of this species using terrestrial camera traps, only arboreal camera traps

IUCN.common.name: Southern Needle-clawed Galago
notes: can't find more detailed ground use data

IUCN.common.name: Northern Needle-clawed Galago
notes: can't find more detailed ground use data

IUCN.common.name: Spectacled Lesser Galago
notes: Mugerwa et al. (2013) only retrieve one CT observation of this species in 60 days of terrestrial CT surveys. Off and Gebo (2005) don't mention any ground use at all using traditional observation methods.

IUCN.common.name: Southern Lesser Galago
notes: Bersacola et al. (2015) shows some ground use for this species but study duration is very short (59 observation hours total)

IUCN.common.name: Kenya Lesser Galago
notes: found this species to use the ground less than 3% of the time during a two-week study

IUCN.common.name: Senegal Lesser Galago
notes: found this species to use the ground less than 3% of the time during a two-week study

IUCN.common.name: Demidoff's Dwarf Galago
notes: Bersacola et al. (2015) shows no ground use for this species but study duration is very short (59 observation hours total)

IUCN.common.name: Angola Dwarf Galago
notes: never seen on ground in 59h observation period

IUCN.common.name: Thomas's Dwarf Galago
notes: Bersacola et al. (2015) shows no ground use for this species but study duration is very short (59 observation hours total). Off and Gebo (2005) don't mention any ground use at all.

IUCN.common.name: Mountain Gorilla
notes: estimate only 3% of time is spent in trees

IUCN.common.name: Western Gorilla
notes: IUCN refers to the western gorillas as semi-terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Cross River Gorilla
notes: IUCN refers to the western gorillas as semi-terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Western Lowland Gorilla
notes: IUCN refers to the western gorillas as semi-terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Alaotra Reed Lemur
notes: according to IUCN, it is the only primate species that lives exclusively in wetlands habitat. Can't find detailed terrestrial data. Diet data from Mutschler et al. (1998) https://www.karger.com/Article/PDF/21647?casa_token=kYinnAdCbG0AAAAA:b3cKWXXnmURyHIcG70OK-lGvVwLKp1lhee7yftOidQ36VeU2muH9njmLIJVpOiptKSCHVP2E

IUCN.common.name: Rusty-gray Lesser Bamboo Lemur
notes: refers to this species as arboreal. Reports percentage of terrestrial feeding events, but this may be of a total feeding time, not percentage of all observations. Also, this study was done in a fragmented and degraded littoral forest

IUCN.common.name: Western Hoolock Gibbon
reference: Hasan et al. (2007) Substrate use by the western hoolock gibbon
notes: notes this species never used the ground

IUCN.common.name: Eastern Hoolock Gibbon
notes: referred to as exculisvley arboreal but Krishna (2012) observed individuals descending to the ground to eat corn, this is in a highly fragmented/degraded and highly anthropogenic environment

IUCN.common.name: Skywalker Hoolock Gibbon
notes: can't find any estimates of ground use, or mention of being strictly arboreal

IUCN.common.name: Abbott’s Gray Gibbon
notes: IUCN states this species has not been studied in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Agile Gibbon
notes: strata use data, no mention of any observations/activity on ground

IUCN.common.name: Bornean White-bearded Gibbon
reference: Unpublished data from Cabang Panti, Indonesia
notes: zero camera trap observations in over 5 years of data from CP

IUCN.common.name: Northern Gray Gibbon
notes: in two year observation period only observed one male, one time, descend to the ground to consume an un-ID mushroom

IUCN.common.name: Pileated Gibbon
notes: IUCN states that there are no long-term behavioral studies of this species

IUCN.common.name: Peruvian Yellow-tailed Woolly Monkey
notes: captured almost exclusively geophagy events on the ground via camera traps

IUCN.common.name: Common Woolly Monkey
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Ring-tailed Lemur
notes: estimates 35% of time spent on ground

IUCN.common.name: Illiger’s Saddle-back Tamarin
notes: states that individuals were seen foraging on in the leaf litter rarely, and never spent more than a few minutes on the ground

IUCN.common.name: Red-mantle Saddle-back Tamarin
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Andean Saddle-back Tamarin
notes: IUCN site says species has not been studied in any detail in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Black Mantle Tamarin
notes: notes the tamarins often foraged on the ground but didn't give an estimate of percent time

IUCN.common.name: Black-faced Lion Tamarin
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Black Lion Tamarin
notes: during entire study only saw one individual descend to ground while chasing a grasshopper, and only for a few seconds

IUCN.common.name: Golden Lion Tamarin
notes: estimate from graph (Fig.5) showing terrestrial use in both captive and free-ranging groups

IUCN.common.name: Antafia Sportive Lemur
notes: all Lepilemur species are referred to as strictly nocturnal and exclusively arboreal. Can't find detailed habitat use for this species. Range is extremely small

IUCN.common.name: Ahmanson’s Sportive Lemur
notes: can't find any data at all on this species

IUCN.common.name: Gray’s Sportive Lemur
notes: can't find habitat use data. Diet data inferred from https://neprimateconservancy.org/grays-sportive-lemur

IUCN.common.name: Milne-Edwards's Sportive Lemur
notes: study doesn't mention any ground use at all

IUCN.common.name: Madame Fleurette’s Sportive Lemur
notes: does not mention ground use at all during entire dissertation research

IUCN.common.name: Hubbard's Sportive Lemur
notes: no field studies of this species are known, only recently named and described. PVA sugests this species is wholly arboreal (Martin et al. 2021 Population estimates of Hubbard's sportive lemur)

IUCN.common.name: James' Sportive Lemur
notes: can't find any data at all on this species

IUCN.common.name: White-footed Sportive Lemur
notes: "Vertical clingers and sleepers", 11 month study of substrate use reports no instances of ground use

IUCN.common.name: Mittermeier's Sportive Lemur
notes: "Field data on the little known and endangered Lepilemur mittermeieri", no note of ground activity

IUCN.common.name: Weasel Sportive Lemur
notes: states that individuals were never seen on the ground

IUCN.common.name: Otto's Sportive Lemur
notes: can't find any data at all on this species

IUCN.common.name: Randrianasolo's Sportive Lemur
notes: can't find any data at all on this species

IUCN.common.name: Sahamalaza Sportive Lemur
notes: "Habitat selection and use in the critically endangered Sahamalaza sportive lemur in altered habitat", no mention of ground use, even in a degraded habitat. Diet data from Seiler (2012) dissertation

IUCN.common.name: Sahafary Sportive Lemur
notes: "The influence of seasonality, disturbance, and cyclonic activity on the behavior of northern sportive lemurs", paper describes strata use in degraged forest before and after cyclones, doesn't report any ground use at all. Diet data from Dinsmore et al. (2016) Variation in Habitat and Behavior of the Northern Sportive Lemur, based on feeding records of 2 individuals in less anthropogenically disturbed area

IUCN.common.name: Nosy Be Sportive Lemur
notes: "Habitat use, diet, and sleeping site selection of Lepilemur tymerlachsoni in a disturbed forest", records no ground use, even in a disturbed forest

IUCN.common.name: Black Mangabey
notes: references both state that this species was seen rarely on the ground, and give estimates for strata use that include 0m but don't specify how much of that is on the ground. No more than 5% of observations on ground (0-6m)

IUCN.common.name: Grey Slender Loris
notes: "Activity budget and positional behavior of the Mysore slendor loris"

IUCN.common.name: Stump-tailed Macaque
reference: Chetry (2002) - an unpublished doctoral thesis, as reported by the IUCN species page
notes: feeding data from IUCN webpage, citing Chetry and Chetry (2015)

IUCN.common.name: Assam Macaque
notes: "Ecology of assamese macaques at Phu Khieo wildlife sanctuary", figure 4 contains bar graph of strata use, including ground

IUCN.common.name: Formosan Rock Macaque
notes: IUCN page states this species is arboreal and terrestrial. Richter et al. (2013) Ecology of an endemic primate species on Siberut Island, Indonesia - reports percent terrestrial in table 2.

IUCN.common.name: Nicobar Crab-eating Macaque
notes: IUCN page describes this species as semiterrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Dark-crowned Long-tailed Macaque
notes: can't find habitat use data. IUCN data deficient

IUCN.common.name: Japanese Macaque
notes: "Positional behavior of free-ranging Japanese macaques", found large sex difference in terrestriality: males 68.3% and females 39.8%. Author refers to males as terrestrial and females arboreal

IUCN.common.name: Japanese Macaque
notes: ATWP estimate of ground use from Hanya unpublished data

IUCN.common.name: Yakushima Macaque
notes: ATWP estimate of ground use from Hanya unpublished data

IUCN.common.name: Heck's Macaque
notes: IUCN page states that this species is largely arboreal, but that it's terrestriality (and all macaque terrestriality) needs more study. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014) https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1890/13-1917.1

IUCN.common.name: Northern Pig-tailed Macaque
reference: Feeroz, M. M. (2011, January). Resource partitioning among the sympatric primate species of West Bhanugach forest reserve of Bangladesh
notes: estiamtes this species and 3 others ground use

IUCN.common.name: Moor Macaque
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Rhesus Monkey
notes: "Resource partitioning among the sympatric primate species of West Bhanugach forest reserve of Bangladesh"

IUCN.common.name: Arunachal Macaque
notes: "Macaca munzala: A new species from Western Arunachal Pradesh, NE India", no systematic observations of strata use, but states most observations are on the ground

IUCN.common.name: Southern Pig-tailed Macaque
notes: "Activity budgets and habitat use of wild southern pig-tailed macaques", compared ground use in primary forest and oil palm. In primary forest, males used the ground 66.9% of the time,  females 52.7%. Both were higher in oil palm, M:73.2% and F:56.5%

IUCN.common.name: Gorontalo Macaque
notes: figure 6.4 shows that strata 0-10m was used 3.4% of the total time, and notes in the chapter state that ground use was not uncommon to see. Terrestriality must be less than 3.4%. Percent fruit from Kohlhaas (1993) dissertation. Body mass from Smith and Jungers (1997) Body mass in comparative primatology

IUCN.common.name: Booted Macaque
notes: can't find habitat use data. IUCN data deficient

IUCN.common.name: Bonnet Macaque
notes: "Characteristics of the social life of Bonnet Macaques", estimates 30% of activity is terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Siberut Macaque
notes: studied one habituated group. Also contains percent fruit data. Body mass data from http://treatment.plazi.org/id/CE199B17FFC9FFCCFFD5624FF654F9FF

IUCN.common.name: Lion-tailed Macaque
notes: "Time budget and activity patterns of the lion-tailed macaque", estimates 0.35% of time on ground, and most of that was spent foraging on mushrooms

IUCN.common.name: Dusky Toque Macaque
reference: Fooden (1979) Taxonomy and evolution of the sinica group of Macaques
notes: states this spp is more strongly arboreal than M.s.sinica

IUCN.common.name: Dry Zone Toque Macaque
notes: "Taxonomy and evolution of the sinica group of Macaques", estimates 24% of total time on ground

IUCN.common.name: Milne-edwards’ Macaque
notes: "Postional behavior and substrate use in wild Tibetan macaques", Diet data from Li et al. (2022) https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ece3.9338

IUCN.common.name: Tonkean Macaque
notes: "Ranging patterns and habitat use of sulawesi tonkean macaques", compared ground use between minimally and heavily altered habitats. Ground use in min. was 0.5%, in heavy 22%

IUCN.common.name: Marca’s Marmoset
notes: IUCN page says no behavioral or ecological studies are available

IUCN.common.name: Maués Marmoset
notes: IUCN page says no behavioral or ecological studies are available

IUCN.common.name: Arnhold's Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page says this species has not been studied in the wild, and little is known about it other than it is arboreal and nocturnal

IUCN.common.name: Ganzhorn's Mouse Lemur
notes: "Habitat utilization of three sympatric Cheirogaleid lemurs", IUCN species page states that the species referred to as M.murinus is actually M.ganzhorni

IUCN.common.name: Jolly's Mouse Lemur
notes: no observations of this species using terrestrial camera traps, only arboreal camera traps

IUCN.common.name: MacArthur's Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page states this species has not been studied in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Margot Marsh's Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page states this species has not been studied in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Marohita Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page states this species' natural history, social system, and life history are unstudied at the moment

IUCN.common.name: Mittermeier's Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page states this species has not been studied in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Grey Mouse Lemur
notes: "Feeding ecology of sympatric mouse lemur species in NW Madagascar", Followed 6 individuals of this species for 120 hours

IUCN.common.name: Peters’ Mouse Lemur
notes: IUCN page states the ecology and behavior of this species has yet to be studied. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Golden-brown Mouse Lemur
notes: Followed 4 individuals of this species for 120 hours. Diet data from Thoren et al. (2011) https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225162714_Seasonal_Changes_in_Feeding_Ecology_and_Activity_Patterns_of_Two_Sympatric_Mouse_Lemur_Species_the_Gray_Mouse_Lemur_Microcebus_murinus_and_the_Golden-brown_Mouse_Lemur_M_ravelobensis_in_Northwestern_M

IUCN.common.name: Rufous Mouse Lemur
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Sambirano Mouse Lemur
notes: "Sleeping and Ranging behavior of the Sambirano mouse lemur, Microcebus sambiransis", reference makes note of following primates through arboreal pathways, no note of ground activity. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Anosy Mouse Lemur
notes: can't find habitat use data. It seems this species was first described in 2013 and has a restricted range that is disturbed to heavily disturbed

IUCN.common.name: Northern Talapoin Monkey
notes: 5% ground use inferred from M. talapoin

IUCN.common.name: Coquerel's Giant Mouse Lemur
notes: "Home range, behaviour and tactile communication in a nocturnal Malagasy lemur Microcebus coquereli"

IUCN.common.name: Northern Giant Mouse Lemur
notes: "Morphology, behavior, ranging patterns, and habitat use of the northern giant mouse lemur"

IUCN.common.name: Black Crested Gibbon
notes: "The critically endangered black crested gibbon on Wuliang Mountain, Yunnan, China"

IUCN.common.name: Bengal Slow Loris
notes: Diet data from Das et al. (2014) https://www.int-res.com/articles/esr_oa/n023p149.pdf

IUCN.common.name: Greater Slow Loris
notes: "Living together in the night: abundance and habitat use of sympatric and allopatric populations of slow lorises and tarsiers"

IUCN.common.name: Javan Slow Loris
notes: Diet data from Cabana et al. (2017) The seasonal feeding ecology of the Javan slow loris

IUCN.common.name: Kayan Slow Loris
notes: IUCN page states that there have been no studies of this species in the wild

IUCN.common.name: Philippine Slow Loris
notes: Diet data inferred from IUCN page

IUCN.common.name: Thick-tailed Greater Galago
notes: Bersacola et al. (2015) shows no ground use for this species but study duration is very short (59 observation hours total)

IUCN.common.name: Bonobo
notes: IUCN page refers to this species as semi-terrestrial. Susman et al. (1980) describe terrestriality increasing only in brief dry season, when fruit availability is low.

IUCN.common.name: Eastern Chimpanzee
notes: "Positional behavior of Pan troglodytes in the Mahale mountains and Gombe stream national parks, Tanzania", well-habituated adults. Ground use Mahale chimps: 60.7%, Gombe chimps: 47.2%. Weighted average based on sample size: 57.3%. Difference between two sites Gombe more open.

IUCN.common.name: Mozambique Dwarf Galago
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Milne-Edwards's Potto
notes: Bersacola et al. (2015) shows no ground use for this species but study duration is very short (59 observation hours total)

IUCN.common.name: Masoala Fork-marked Lemur
notes: "Territorial pairs but low cohesion between pair partners in a nocturnal lemur", authors note scurrying on ground to escape agonistic interactions the only time this species is seen on the ground. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Sambirano Fork-marked Lemur
notes: IUCN page states ecology and behavior of this species has not been systematically researched, but are found high in canopy of tall trees

IUCN.common.name: Western Red Colobus
notes: McGraw (1998) data on strata use finds this species to use the ground 0.1% of the time

IUCN.common.name: Niger Delta Red Colobus
notes: JLR Werre Ph.D. thesis: Ecology and Behavior of the Niger Delta Red Colobus Monkey. Can't find access to it online.

IUCN.common.name: Foa's Red Colobus
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Ashy Red Colobus
notes: Diet data from Kibaja (2014) Diet of the Ashy Red Colobus

IUCN.common.name: Equatorial Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events

IUCN.common.name: Buffy Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events

IUCN.common.name: Gray’s Bald-faced Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events. Diet data from Palminteri (2010) dissertationhttps://ueaeprints.uea.ac.uk/id/eprint/20507/1/2010PalminteriSPhD.pdf

IUCN.common.name: Monk Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing very few terrestrial events

IUCN.common.name: Pissinatti’s Saki
notes: can't find habitat use data. IUCN data deficient

IUCN.common.name: White-faced Saki
notes: reports on multiple published and unpublished data showing some terrestrial events, no estiamte for percentage of terrestriality though, only number of events

IUCN.common.name: Prince Bernhard’s Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed. Unpublished systematic data from K.G.D. Lopes shows 97 terrestrial observations in a 6 month period, but unclear if this is multiple groups or individuals

IUCN.common.name: Brown Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Chestnut-bellied Titi
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Caquetá Tití Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed. Diet data from Villota et al. (2021) Mammalian Species - mammalogy.org

IUCN.common.name: Ashy Black Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Coppery Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Red Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Bolivian Gray Titi
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Hershkovitz's Titi
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Hoffmann’s Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Beni Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Red-bellied Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: San Martin Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed. Weight data from https://www.gbif.org/species/2436381

IUCN.common.name: Olalla Brothers’ Titi
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Ornate Tití Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Chacoan Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Toppin’s Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Vieira's Titi Monkey
notes: reports on published and unpublished data showing  few terrestrial events witnessed

IUCN.common.name: Sumatran Orangutan
notes: IUCN page reports that males rarely travel on ground but females virtually never do.

IUCN.common.name: Northeast Bornean Orangutan
notes: Loken et al. (2013) is a CT-only study so does not report percentage

IUCN.common.name: Southwest Bornean Orangutan
notes: "Why do orangutans leave the trees?", average of 2.29% time on ground. Statistically significant difference between flanged males (more time on ground) compared to females.

IUCN.common.name: Hose’s Langur
notes: "Ecology and conservation of the Hose's Langur group"

IUCN.common.name: Golden-bellied Mentawai Island Langur
notes: "Habitat use and tropic niche overlap of two sympatric colobines"

IUCN.common.name: Red Langur
notes: "Down from the treetops: red langur terrestrial behavior", focal observations of fully habituated groups

IUCN.common.name: Olive Colobus
notes: McGraw (1998) data on strata use finds this species uses ground 5.7% of the time

IUCN.common.name: Greater Bamboo Lemur
notes: "Terrestrialite et domaine vital chez Prolemur simus dAmbalafary", finds strong seasonality of terrestriality in the species, ranging from 0 to up to 30% of time spent on the ground between Dec. and Mar., coinciding with an abundance of bamboo shoots

IUCN.common.name: Silky Sifaka
notes: " An ethnoprimatological assessment of human impact on the parasite ecology of silky sifaka"

IUCN.common.name: Van der Decken’s Sifaka
notes: can't find habitat data. Diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkey
notes: "Dissertation: Positional Behavior and support use of the Tonkin Snub-nosed monkeys", reports no ground use

IUCN.common.name: Black Snub-nosed Monkey
notes: "Substrate use and postural behavior in free-ranging snub-nosed monkeys"

IUCN.common.name: Grey Snub-nosed Monkey
notes: "Preliminary results from a field study of wild Guizhou snub-nosed monkeys", diet data from IUCN page

IUCN.common.name: Golden Snub-nosed Monkey
notes: estimates 27% ground use. Body mass reported in Zhu et al. (2015) https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/ajp.22314?casa_token=wxHFKb-lQekAAAAA:fqlmUm-dFhKpd1L3_DWwlWhapi3J6-HCk8L-Sifb0OxuY0xfpnv3W3cM_p0bDPIjxZXoSYolVZq6XA

IUCN.common.name: Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey
notes: "Positional behavior and canopy use of black snub-nosed monkeys", only saw the focal group use the ground twice

IUCN.common.name: Kipunji
notes: "The critically endangered kipunji ", reference states that species is primarily arboreal but is known to descend to the ground to raid crops. Diet data from Davenport et al. (2010) Diet and feeding patterns in the kipunji

IUCN.common.name: Pied Tamarin
notes: Vidal and Cintra (2006) noted that this species descended to the ground during periods of food scarcity, during the dry season

IUCN.common.name: Geoffroy’s Tamarin
notes: "The use of time and space by the Panamanian tamarin", notes that these tamarins use the ground occasionally in the dry season

IUCN.common.name: Silvery-brown Tamarin
notes: Diet data from Poveda and Sanchez-Palomini (2004) Habitat use by the white-footed tamarin

IUCN.common.name: Martin's Ochraceous Bare-face Tamarin
notes: "New records of Martin's bare-faced tamarin", notes that these tamarins were always found in the middle strata of the forest, up to 20m high

IUCN.common.name: Cotton-headed Tamarin
notes: Diet data from Garcia-Castillo and Defler (2018) The diet of S.oedipus in a dry tropical forest

IUCN.common.name: Collins' Squirrel Monkey
notes: "The foraging ecology of male and female squirrel monkeys", notes that males used the ground more than females, but both used sparsely. Does not include percentage of ground use.

IUCN.common.name: Guianan Squirrel Monkey
notes: "Activity budget, diet, and use of space by two groups of squirrel monkeys in Eastern Amazonia", both groups oberved for ~280h. One group used the ground 9.4%, the other 4.4%. Reporting the mean since both were followed for the same amount of time.

IUCN.common.name: Golden-backed Squirrel Monkey
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Black-capped Capuchin
notes: " Positional behavior and substrate use in wild adult bearded capuchin monkeys", terrestriality data from Tab.3

IUCN.common.name: Blonde Capuchin
notes: found in Brazil's coastal forest. Inhabits many fragmented areas. Seems to be highly resistant to anthropogenic disturbance.

IUCN.common.name: Bearded Capuchin
notes: Highly resistant to anthropogenic disturbance. Reference table 3 has citations for other studies of capuchin ground use. Wright et al. (2019) data from Cerrado (dry) forest, in Fazeda Boa Vista, Piaui, Brazil

IUCN.common.name: Buff-headed Capuchin
notes: "The distributions, habitat use, and conservation status of three Atlantic Forest Monkeys in an agroforestry/forest mosaic in Southern Bahia, Brazil", diet data from IUCN page

IUCN.common.name: Gabon Squirrel Galago
notes: IUCN states that this species forages on the ground occasionally

IUCN.common.name: Kashmir Gray Langur
notes: "Social organization and reproductive biology of the humalayan grey langur"

IUCN.common.name: Southern Plains Gray Langur
notes: this species might need to be scrapped, as IUCN states this should be S. hypoleucos instead. The Powell data set considers this species.

IUCN.common.name: Northern Plains Gray Langur
notes: "Feeding and ranging patterns of forest Hanuman langurs (Presbytis entellus)", habituated group followed for 1,853 contact hours. Kanha Tiger Reserve

IUCN.common.name: Tarai Gray Langur
notes: states this species is arboreal, but mainly terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Black-footed Gray Langur
notes: "Folivory as a constraint on social behavior of langurs in South India", IUCN states they are arboreal, semi-terrestrial. Are unusual among the genus in that they are wet forest forms.

IUCN.common.name: Tufted Gray Langur
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Nepal Gray Langur
notes: IUCN states this species is mainly terrestrial but may use high canopy to escape danger

IUCN.common.name: Pig-tailed Snub-nosed Langur
notes: "Habitat use and tropic niche overlap of two sympatric colobines"

IUCN.common.name: Dian's Tarsier
notes: diet data from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: NA
notes: can't find habitat data. It looks like this species was only recently described (Shekelle et al. 2019). IUCN states that no field work has been done on this species.

IUCN.common.name: Siau Island Tarsier
notes: can't find habitat data. IUCn states this species has not been the subject of systematic study

IUCN.common.name: Wallace’s Tarsier
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Gelada
notes: "Ecological relations and niche separation between sympatric terrestrial primates in Ethiopia", percentage is based on number of individuals in the trees or on the ground for all scans

IUCN.common.name: Tenasserim Lutung
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Silvery Lutung
notes: can't find detailed habitat use data

IUCN.common.name: Delacour's Langur
notes: "Positional behavior of Delacour's Langurs", species is restricted to limestone karst forest, with large rocky outcrops. Workman and Schmitt (2012) estimate over 80% of time on rocks, but doesn't specify if this is near ground level or not.

IUCN.common.name: François’s Langur
notes: "Comparison of locomotor behaviour between white-headed langurs Trachipythecus leucocephalus and Francois' langurs T. francoisi in Fusui, China"

IUCN.common.name: Hatinh Langur
notes: "Observations on the Hatinh langur during point and line transect sampling in the Phong Nha - Ke Bang National Park, Central Vietnam"

IUCN.common.name: Laotian Langur
notes: "Some observations on the Hatinh langur in North Central Vietnam"

IUCN.common.name: Spectacled Leaf Monkey
notes: "Activities, habitat use, and diet of wild dusky langurs"

IUCN.common.name: Phayre’s Leaf-monkey
notes: "Dissertation: Molecular phylogenetic status and ecological characteristics of Pharye's leaf monkey in Myanmar", not including the strata use of ground1, which refers to rocky outcrop use. Similar to the definition of other species in this genus using karst and limestone outcrops

IUCN.common.name: Indochinese Gray Langur
notes: "Living in forests: strata use by Indo-Chinese gray langurs", refers to Trachypithecus crepusculus

IUCN.common.name: Capped Langur
notes: states no observations of this species on the ground were made

IUCN.common.name: Cat Ba Hooded Black Leaf Monkey
notes: "Home range size and habitat use by Cat Ba Langurs in a disturbed and fragmented habitat", body mass from Wilman et al. (2014)

IUCN.common.name: Shortridge’s Langur
notes: states this species is arboreal, sometimes terrestrial

IUCN.common.name: Black-and-white Ruffed Lemur
notes: no observations of this species using terrestrial camera traps, only arboreal camera traps
